Excluding Files in IntelliJ IDEA | Generated by AI

Home 2025.10

In IntelliJ IDEA, you can exclude files or directories so they don‚Äôt appear in search, indexing, code completion, or builds. There are several ways to do it depending on your purpose:

1. Mark a Directory as Excluded

  • In the Project view, right-click the folder you want to exclude.
  • Choose Mark Directory as ‚Üí Excluded.
  • IDEA will stop indexing it, so it won‚Äôt show up in searches, navigation, or code analysis.

This is typically used for build output folders (target/, out/, dist/, etc.).

2. Exclude from Version Control (VCS Ignore)

If you don‚Äôt want IDEA (and Git) to track certain files:

  • Create or edit a .gitignore file in your project.
  • Add the directory or filename patterns there.
  • IDEA will recognize .gitignore and hide them from VCS operations.

3. Exclude Files from Code Analysis / Inspections

  • Go to Settings ‚Üí Editor ‚Üí Inspections.
  • There you can configure Scopes, and assign inspections only to certain file sets while excluding others.

4. Exclude from Build (Gradle/Maven)

If you‚Äôre using Gradle or Maven, you can configure build.gradle or pom.xml to exclude certain directories (like generated code or resources). IDEA respects these build tool configurations.

5. Exclude Specific File Types

  • Go to Settings ‚Üí Editor ‚Üí File Types.
  • Add patterns (like *.log, *.tmp) to the ‚ÄúIgnore files and folders‚Äù list.

üëâ Quick tip: If your goal is just to stop IDEA from wasting resources indexing large folders (like node_modules/), the Mark Directory as Excluded option is the fastest and most effective.
